edu.missouri.bayesianConstructor

Class NodePlacer

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.missouri.bayesianConstructor.NodePlacer

  • public class NodePlacer
extends java.lang.Object
    The NodePlacer class computes the best placement for the given node on the canvas on which its graph is displayed. The class works primarily under the assumption that the nodes can be grouped into components such as the "layers" in a DomainKnowledge model. Components must be assigned a fixed order before calling, giving each an immediate predecessor and an immediate successor in the order (which need not be related to how the components connect).

    The class can plot several configurations:

    • Geometric: the class can place the nodes following a geometric shape. In this scenario, each component is assigned one of the sides, and there are as many sides as they are components (for example, if nodes are grouped into three components, they will be placed along the border of a triangle). This configuration is preferred when there may be relations among the members of all the components.
    • Layered: the class can place the nodes stacked by component. Under this configuration, all the nodes of a component are placed along a line, and every other component's nodes follow a line parallel to it. This configuration is preferred when relations are restricted to the immediately preceding and the immediately following component.
    • Asterisk: the class places each component along a line radiating from the center. This configuration is preferred when relations are restricted to the immediately preceding and the immediately following component, with possible relations between the first and last components.
    • Star: The members of a component are placed along a circle The circles are also placed along a circle, except for the first component which is placed in the center. This configuration is preferred if there is one central component which is known to be the source of all others, or which is known to be the sink of all others, and every other component interacts with this central component; and optionally, with the one immediately preceding it, and the one immediately following it. It is not recommended if, for example, there is a five-component structure and the second component interacts with the third, as this will cause arcs to cut through the center component.
    The placements are affected by an angle and a leeway parameter. The angle affects the initial orientation of the graph; for instance, whether a star cluster should have a point directly above the center, or whether the lines described by the components are horizontal, vertical, or diagonal. The leeway parameter establishes how much space should be given to each node. By default, leeway is set to 128 pixels, which is a good minimum size for the SamIam viewer. For other viewers (such as the Weka viewer which does not truncate the variable name) larger sizes may be desired.

    The angle parameter can also be used to specify direction in the case of layered placement: an angle of π/2 will place each component's nodes on a vertical line, with its successor to its right, while an angle of -π/2 (or 3π/2) will place each component's nodes on a vertical line, with its successor to its left.

    The canvas size is an important parameter to determine the positions as it will indicate the center of the plot. Because this is often hard to estimate, constructors are provided that perform a calculation of the estimated space needed, such as NodePlacer(int, int, int, double, char). Note that if canvas size is not properly set, negative values may be returned as the class tries to enforce the leeway.

    Once initialized, the class will give the computed position for each node by calling {link #position(int, int, int, int)}. Using a larger number of components than what will actually be graphed can allow creativity in the result. For example, a graph may be made to look like a satellite dish by using the "star" configuration and specifying twice the number of components it actually has.

    Parameters are defined as final to prevent callers from changing them and causing erratic behavior.

    Since:
    bayesianConstructor version 0.10 2016-03-29
    Version:
    1.4 2016-03-30
    Author:
    Fernando J. Torre-Mora

    • Field Detail

      • angle

        public final double angle
        Specifies the angle (in radians) at which all placement computations should start. An angle of zero specifies a horizontal line, while an angle of Math.PI/2 specifies a vertical line going up. The default angle is zero radians. Note that once this value is set, it can no longer be changed.

      • DEFAULT_ANGLE

        private static final double DEFAULT_ANGLE
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • leeway

        public final int leeway
        Number of pixels to leave unoccupied around each node. Should be greater than the size a node is expected to take up in the final placing. The default leeway is 128. Note that once this value is set, it can no longer be changed.

      • DEFAULT_LEEWAY

        private static final int DEFAULT_LEEWAY
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • canvas

        public final int canvas
        Number of pixels the graph is expected to take up. The canvas is assumed to be square. The default value is 480 pixels in honor of the original VGA monitor standard. Note that once this value is set, it can no longer be changed.

      • DEFAULT_CANVAS

        private static final int DEFAULT_CANVAS
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • maxSize

        public final int maxSize
        Maximum number of elements a component is allowed to have.

      • configuration

        public final char configuration
        Stores which configuration will be used. The constructors enforce this to only be one of the supported configurations. 'G' is used for the Geometric configuration, 'L' for the Layered configuration, and 'S' for the Star configuration. These constants are also provided as members and are encouraged for improved maintainability. Note that once this value is set, it can no longer be changed.

      • GEOMETRIC

        public static final char GEOMETRIC
        Value for configuration for the geometric configuration (G)
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • LAYERED

        public static final char LAYERED
        Value for configuration for the layered configuration (L)
        See Also:

      • computeCanvas

        public int computeCanvas(int components)
        Computes the size of the canvas needed to plot a graph with the specified number of components and nodes. This function assumes that leeway and configuration have already been initialized.
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the number of pixels needed to plot this graph

      • nodeOffset

        public java.awt.Point nodeOffset(int component,
                                 int node,
                                 int number,
                                 int size)
        Computes the offset of the desired node from the center of the desired component
        Parameters:

        node - Number of the desired node within the component
        number - Total number of components
        size - Total number of nodes in this component

      • position
